titlePage.titlePart:
ABOUT
Western Reserve University
IN THE
CITY OF CLEVELAND Western Reserve University logo WITH VIEWS OF THE CAMPUS
1919

figure.head: Amasa Stone, Memorial Chapel, Adelbert College
figure.figDesc: Amasa Stone, Memorial Chapel, Adelbert College

div.head: What About College?
div.p: COLLEGE.-TRAINED leaders guided this country to victory in the recent war. Government statistics show vividly how this nation turned, as did other nations, to the product of its higher educational institutions for leadership, without which the valor of its soldiers and sailors would have been unavailing.
But the war served only to emphasize a peace-time truth. The college trained men are the leaders in peace no less than in war.
For years we have demanded special training for ministers, physicians. surgeons and lawyers. Professional men are college men.

And now the business world is demanding college training for its men and women, that they may strive better in the competition of present day industrialism. A college education has become as essential for a successful career in business, politics and social work, with their hundreds of ramifications, as it is in the professions and in engineering.

This booklet is sent to you so that you may know about Western Reserve University as you make your plans for a college education. Western Reserve can train you either in the law, medical, dental and teaching professions, or for the business world.

A University offers opportunities which a college, whether it be large or small, cannot offer. Not only docs it aid in specialization, but also it gives that rounded development and general culture which are the marks of a well-educated man or woman.

If the University is located in a city, the advantages are multiplied.as opportunities for contacts and associations of the most varied character are offered. The student is surrounded by a vast laboratory in which to study and to become familiar with the vital elements in the organization of modern society. Moral development is individual, and the city brings to the student no greater temptations than the small town, while it gives him better and safer opportunities for utilizing that energy which otherwise might be ill-directed.
Western Reserve wants you if it can meet your need. Tell us about that need. Address the Executive Secretary of the University.
You should keep this booklet for future information.

figure.figDesc: Portion of Adelbert College Campus, Showing Main Building and Amasa Stone Chapel
figure.head: Portion of Adelbert College Campus, Showing Main Building and Amasa Stone Chapel

div.p: ADELBERT COLLEGE is the men's college of liberal arts and sciences of the University, the four-year course leading to the degree of Bachelor of Arts. It is the department for the man who wishes a general University training, with opportunity for specialization in English. Foreign Languages. Political and Social Sciences, Philosophy, History and the natural sciences. The graduate is prepared for teaching or for business.

The work of Adelbert College is preparatory to that of the School of Medicine and the Law School of the University and to the combined course in Engineering offered by Western Reserve and Case School of Applied Science. Pre medical and pre-law courses are so arranged as to permit the student to devote the whole of his senior year at Adelbert to work in the School of medicine or the Law School, thus shortening the entire course by one year.
ThThe curriculum of Adelbert College offers the following general fields in which the student may find his chief interest:

list.item: A. Language and Literature; Biblical Literature, English, German. Latin,French. Spanish. Italian.
B. .Mathematics and Natural Science; Astronomy, Biology, Chemistry,Geology, .Mathematics, Physics
C. Philosophy, History and Social Sciences; Economics, History, Philosophy, Political Science. Sociology.

div.p: In general, graduation from a first grade high school is necessary for admission. For details prospective students should write to the Dean. Adelbert College. Western Reserve University.

figure.figDesc: An Autumn View on the Adelbert College Campus
figure.head: An Autumn View on the Adelbert College Campus

figure.figDesc: The Mather Quadrangle, College for Women
figure.head: The Mather Quadrangle, College for Women

div.p: THE COLLEGE FOR WOMEN is the women's college of liberal arts and sciences, with four year courses leading to the degrees of Bachelor of Arts or Bachelor of Science. The courses of study leading to the degree of Bachelor of Arts are divided into three groups: Language and Literature, Mathematics and Science, and History, Philosophy and Social Science. It is designed for the woman who desires a liberal and less technical education.

The course leading to the degree of Bachelor of Science, known as the Household Administration course, is designed to train women for specialized lines of work. Courses have been arranged preparatory to four distinct lines of endeavor: (1.) Teaching the household arts, (2) Laboratory research, (3)Hospital work, (4) Social service.

Combined courses are offered with the Library School, the Law School,and the School of Medicine, of the University, and with the Cleveland School of Art. The course with the School of Art covers six years and leads to the degree of Bachelor of Science.
In general, graduation from a first-class high school is required for admission. For details prospective students should write to the Dean, College for Women,Western Reserve University.

figure.figDesc: The Painter Memorial Gateway,College for Women
figure.head: The Painter Memorial Gateway,College for Women

div.p: THE GRADUATE: SCHOOL is open to students who have received a bachelor's degree from an approved institution. During the present reorganization of the School, students interested in graduate work should consult with the deans of the undergraduate departments.

figure.figDesc: Flora Stone Mather Memorial Building, College for Women
figure.head: Flora Stone Mather Memorial Building, College for Women

div.p: THE SCHOOL OF MEDICINE;, which oilers a four-year course, admits only college graduates or seniors in absentia. Certain entrance; requirements demanded of all prospective students are: One and one-half years college work in Chemistry, including three semester hours of Organic Chemistry; One year of college work in Physics;One year of college work in Biology. Zoology and Botany; eight semester hours of work in French or

German, of which two semester hours may be credited from one unit of high school work; A total of not less than six semester hours of work in English. For detailed information prospective students should write to the Registrar,The School of Medicine, Western Reserve University.

By taking the combined course offered by Adelbert College or the College for Women and the School of Medicine of the University, students may complete their undergraduate and medical training in seven years instead of the usual eight. Such students spend their first three years in the undergraduate department, and the last four years in the School of Medicine. They receive the A. B. degree at the end of the fourth year, and the M. 1). degree at the end of the. seventh.

figure.figDesc: On the College for Women Campus (1) Mary Chisholm Painter Memorial, (2) Clark Hall,(3) Looking toward Euclid Avenue-, (4) Haydn Hall.
figure.head: On the College for Women Campus (1) Mary Chisholm Painter Memorial, (2) Clark Hall,(3) Looking toward Euclid Avenue-, (4) Haydn Hall.

div.p: The only medical school in a large city, the School of .Medicine has unlimited clinical advantages. Four large Cleveland hospitals. with more than twelve hundred beds and nineteen thousand patients, are controlled by the School. In four other hospitals a certain amount of teaching is done by courtesy of the staff Graduates have splendid opportunities for hospital appointments under these circumstances,

With the close of the war, plans postponed in HM7 are being pushed, and the early completion of the new School of Medicine, Lakeside Hospital, Babies Dispensary and Hospital and other buildings upon the University campus is promised.
The Western Reserve School of Medicine ranks by common consent high among the best schools of the country. It is the only school in the country giving seniors eleven months training instead of eight.

THE LAW SCHOOL is one of the sever, law schools in the country admitting only n.cn with college degrees. The course is three years. Students from thirty-six different colleges are in attendance at present.

By special arrangement students at Adelbert College and the College for Women may spend their entire senior year at the Law School, rims shortening tile complete course from seven to six years. They receive their A. B degree at the end of the fourth year, and their LL. B. degree at the end of the six years.

Emphasis is placed upon the development of the power of legal reasoning by each student, and the case method of instruction is used. The municipal,county, and federal courts in Cleveland present unusual and valuable opportunities for observation. Certain upperclassmen each year deal with actual cases as assistants to the Legal Aid Society of Cleveland.

The Law School as a part of the University offers additional advantages. Courses in Medical Jurisprudence in the School of Medicine and Dental Jurisprudence
in the Dental School are open to Law School students. They may also take courses in Political Science, Sociology, History and such subjects given at Adelbert College.

College men returning from service will be given credit for college work equivalent to the lime spent in the service. They should communicate with Professor CM. Finfrock, Secretary, The Law School,Western Reserve University.

figure.figDesc: The Museum of Art from the Campus
figure.head: The Museum of Art from the Campus

div.p:
THE DENTAL SCHOOL offers a four-year course in dentistry, leading to the degree of D. D. S. The Museum of Art from the Campus
The Museum of Art from the Campus It is located on the main campus in the new three-story building which contains the latest equipment and laboratory facilities.

Being the only dental school in a large city, the Western Reserve dental school offers unique clinical opportunities. The Clinic is equipped with 90 modem dental chairs, in which are performed 40.000 operations annually under expert supervision.
Only graduates of first-class high schools can be admitted to the dental school. This requirement, and the introduction of the four-year course, place the School among the best in the country.

Students of the Dental School are eligible for University athletics, and participate in football, basketball, baseball and track. With its new location on the campus, Dental School participation in University undergraduate activities has increased greatly. University library and museum facilities are all open to the Dental students.

figure.figDesc: Morley Laboratory of Chemistry and Geology, Adelbert College
figure.head: Morley Laboratory of Chemistry and Geology, Adelbert College

div.p: Women are admitted to the Dental School.
Detailed information can be obtained from Doctor F. M. Casto, Dean, the Dental School, Western Reserve University.
THE LIBRARY SCHOOL offers a one-year course to both men and women. It is situated in a separate building, on the Adelbert College campus.

Close connection with the Cleveland Public Library, the fourth largest in the country, gives unequalled opportunity to Library School students. The University libraries and other libraries in the city, with the Public Library, have overdone million volumes.
By special arrangement. College for Women students may receive full credit of one year for the Library School course.
For full information,prospective students should address The Director, the Library School, Western Reserve University.

figure.figDesc: Some of the Rare Books, Hatch Library
Amasa Stone Memorial Hearth, Main Building, Adelbert College
figure.head: Amasa Stone Memorial Hearth, Main Building, Adelbert College

div.p: THE SCHOOL OF PHARMACY offers two courses. The first is two years in length leading to the degree of Graduate in Pharmacy (Ph. G.I, and prepares students to become practical pharmacists. The second course extends over three years, and leads to the degree of Pharmaceutical Chemist(Ph.G.I. Plans to offer a four-year course,leading to baccalaureate and scientific decrees, are under consideration.
To pain admission, men and women must be graduates of first-class high schools, or the equivalent, and must procure entrance certificates from the state board of pharmacy.Columbus, Ohio.
The School of Pharmacy has the cooperation and support of Cleveland druggists,which means unusual opportunities to students for their practical work and for employment.
Catalogue and details may be obtained from Professor Edward Spease,,Dean, School of Pharmacy, Western Reserve

THE SCHOOL OF APPLIED SOCIAL SCIENCES is organized on a graduate basis, and offers a two-year course, leading to the A. M. degree. By arrangement with the Dean courses may be taken in the School without regard to the award of a degree.

The School offers instruction in subjects which bear directly on the common welfare and on community organization by specialists in the fields of Political Science and Administration, Sociology, Economics and Civic Organization. It is separated into: (1) Division of Municipal Administration and public Service, (2) Division of Family Welfare and Social Service, (3) Division of Health Administration. The latter Division gives courses leading into Public Health nursing.

The courses in all Divisions arc kept flexible, in order to meet individual needs. Practical training for professional, social and civic work is the aim throughout. Fully one-half of the student's time is devoted to Field Work.'I he large city of Cleveland affords the best opportunity for this in its civic and social organizations.
Students of Adelbert College and the College for Women can so arrange their work as to complete the course of the School of Applied Social Sciences in one year.
Interested persons should communicate with the Dean. School of Applied Social Science, Western Reserve University.

THE SCHOOL OF EDUCATION is a summer session, designed mainly for teachers, and conducted in cooperation with the Cleveland School of Education. Complete information may be obtained from the Dean. Cleveland School of Education.
PRE-PROFESSIONAL OPPORTUNITIES

It will be noted that distinct advantages come to the student electing the combined courses of Adelbert College or the College for Women with the Law School, the School of Medicine, the Library School and the School of Applied Social Sciences.

The University also oilers a five-year course in Engineering in combination with Case School of Applied Sciences, Cleveland. It is designed for the man who recognizes the demand for engineers with a broader training, a greater breadth of view, than the strictly technical course can give. The first three years arc spent mainly at Adelbert College, the last two years at Case School. Two degrees are earned. Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Science.
EXPENSES

Tuition fees of the various departments are: Adelbert College, College for Women, School of Medicine, Law School, and School of Applied Social Sciences, $I50.00 per year; School of Pharmacy. $125.00 per year; dental school, S200.00 per year; Library School, $100.00 per year.
Other expenses, such as board and room, will vary according to the student. $400 is a fair allowance for them.

The University cooperates with students through the Rooming Bureau and the Employment Bureau, in the office of the Executive Secretary. Rooms and board are secured at reasonable terms. The city offers unlimited employment opportunities for students desiring to earn a part of their expenses. The employment Bureau cannot guarantee positions, but has never experienced difficulty in placing applicants.
STUDENT ACTIVITIES

There are at Western Reserve, in every department, student activities of literary, oratorical, musical, dramatic and social natures, conducted with faculty-approval and cooperation. These afford the student opportunity for profitable development along lines of his own choosing, and furnish legitimate outlets for his surplus energy.

figure.figDesc: An Open-Air Play College for Women

div.p: The College for Women and Adelbert College each have dramatic, musical and literary clubs. The former has its Y. W. C. A. and the latter its Y. M. C. A,organization. At Adelbert College intercollegiate debating and extempore and oratorical contests are promoted. Dental School men are eligible for participation in many of these activities, and have organizations of their own.

The Sketlioi is the Adelbert College annual, published by the Juniors. TheVaria Historia is the College for Women annual, published by the Juniors. The Reserve Weekly is the University undergraduate newspaper. The Sun Dial is a literary magazine published bi-weekly by the College
tor Women students.

The strength of the student personnel is shown by the fact that all of these activities arc self-governed. The Stu-dent Councils of Adelbert College, the Dental School, the School of Medicine,and the College for Women, composed entirely of students elected by their fellows, regulate all student affairs with general cooperation of the faculty. The Honor System of examinations is maintained by these organizations. Student activities are supported by the budget systems, each student being assessed his share at the time of paying his tuition.
The University Student Council has supervision over activities affecting two or more departments.

div.head: ATHLETICS
div.p: The completion of Western Reserve's new $I75,000 gymnasium in the spring of 1909 brings to the University a new era in athletics. This building has one of the largest floors of University gymnasiums, measuring 175 feet by 90 feet. The old gymnasium has been remodeled for auxiliary purposes, and adequate showers, lockers and equipment are provided. The swimming pool will be added in the near future.

Support and control of athletics is now centered in the department of Physical Education, and continued prominence of Western Reserve varsity teams is assured. In addition, the plan of universal training now being considerered will give every man recreational gymnastics throughout his college course. Universal participation in athletic events as well as specialization by a few will be the aim. Inter-class, inter-fraternity and other teams will furnish the material from which the football, basketball, baseball and track Varsities will be drawn.

The College for Women has its own gymnasium, which is open to Library School students. Western Reserve has no inter-collegiate women's teams, but inter class and individual competition is keen. Three hours a week gymnasium exercise is required of all freshmen and sophomores, and special exercises are prescribed for individual corrective work.
The annual classic events are the intra-mural basketball championship contest and the spring outdoor track meet.

div.head: FRATERNITIES
div.p: There are at Western Reserve undergraduate, professional, and honorary fraternities as given below. The undergraduate chapters at Adelbert College are-united hv an Inter fraternity Council, which determines "rushing" rules and cares for other matters of common interest. There is close cooperation between the council and the college faculty. The chapters compete for the Interfraternity Scholarship Trophy, awarded by the Dean each semester.

row.cell: Delta Tan Delta, 1 I H7 Euclid Avenue
Phi Beta Kappa --Scholarship. Adelbert College and the College for Women
Delta Sigma Rho --Debating. Adelbert College. Law School
Order of the Coif --Scholarship. The Law School
Alpha Omega Alpha --Scholarship. The School of Medicine

div.head: IN GENERAL
div.p: The first department of Western Reserve University was established at Hudson, Ohio, in 1826, as Western Reserve College. Removed to Cleveland in 1882, it became Adelbert College of Western Reserve University. Other departments were presently added.

The University campus lies in the midst of the great park system of Cleveland. At the present time eighteen of the twenty-two buildings which house the University are here situated. Additional buildings for the Schools of Medicine and of Pharmacy are soon to be built, so that these departments may be transferred from their present locations in the midst of the city to the University group. With the athletic field, about thirty-seven acres are devoted to University purposes.

In close proximity are the Case School of Applied Science, the Cleveland Museum of Art, the Cleveland Art School, the Cleveland Normal School, the Western Reserve Historical Society, the East End Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, and other public institutions.
The University and the departmental libraries represent about 135,000volumes. The Cleveland Public Library, of 700.000 volumes, has a branch in one of the University buildings.
The University has 7500 alumni and 2000 alumnae and former students, a total of 9500, of whom 7000 are living.
The normal annual enrollment of recent years has been about 1650, This does not include the students in the extension divisions, who number about2350, making a total of some 4000.
Further information will be gladly furnished through the office of the several departments or the general office of the president.
